blog.description: Mibba is a creative writing site designed for authors to share their stories, poems and articles and gain feedback from a growing audience.

summary: And Now We Run.
title: And Now We Run.
body:
Always running. Always being hunted.

I’m The Doctor (5)

“Who are you?” Ashley demanded as the mysterious man started prancing around the strange looking controls. “And what is… This place?” She asked, staring at in in awe..It was huge. That was all she…

Read more…

blog.name: whovianfloozy
blog.title: The Whovian Floozy
blog.description:
My fandom name is Beachy, and this is a multi-fandom blog. 
I'm also a multi-shipper. It's likely I do not sail your ship, but I don't wank and expect visitors to play nicely as well. That includes not adding hate or negativity to my posts, altering them to suit your own ships, or removing my original comments. If you do, you will be blocked.
IRL they call me Doctor. Yep, I'm that old. Sometimes I write things that other people watch. It's all good! I like mocha latte with bourbon. A lot.

blog.description:
Mostly David Tennant and Doctor Who stuff, with a bit of Shakespeare thrown in.
Older than your average tumblr user.  Apparently I have a thing for looooong posts.

tags: I love behind the scenes stuff
(and he loves when he can do the stunts himself - bless him)
it must drive the special effects coordinators a bit mad
trying to keep everyone safe whilst making it look spectacular
(and that last sentence about JohnB cracks me up)
summary:
Behind the scenes of The Sound of Drums/The Last of the Time Lords (Part Seven) 

  

Excerpt from Doctor Who Magazine #385 -...
caption:
Behind the scenes of The Sound of Drums/The Last of the Time Lords
(Part Seven)

Excerpt from Doctor Who Magazine #385 - Any Effects’ Danny Hargreaves (Special Effects Supervisor) interviewed by Benjamin Cook:

DWM: What was the toughest thing to get right?

Danny: There were many problematic moments - mostly involving the main artists, for obvious reasons. When we blew up Martha’s flat, for instance, you have David, Freema, and John running out of the building, just before the blast. That kind of stuff’s very taxing: it’s not like we just turn up and rig the explosion! It takes weeks of preparation, evaluation, and conversation with production. We did several tests the day before and used a gas explosion, which makes it much more controllable than a pyro blast. That, together with factors like building a fire-protective box just inside the window, makes it possible to use the main artists. They were all smiling afterwards! The scene in which Jack fires at the TARDIS’ central column was also difficult, seeing as the TARDIS is quite a flammable set!

DWM: Was that the most nerve-wracking moment?

Danny: No, that was probably the scene in which police fire though the back window of a car with Martha driving, the Doctor in the passenger seat and Captain Jack in the back! Once again, you’re dealing with the three main artists, so it’s very problematic. I was on the floor, in a very uncomfortable position, triggering the bullet-hits, using the actors’ dialogue as my cues. I was hidden at John’s feet and climbing all over them, which he found hilarious!

Previous parts are available here: [one] [two] [three] [four] [five] [six] [seven] [eight]
Other behind-the-scenes photosets are available here

Thank you to everyone who shared set photos!

(Part Seven)

Excerpt from Doctor Who Magazine #385 - Any Effects’ Danny Hargreaves (Special Effects Supervisor) interviewed by Benjamin Cook:

DWM: What was the toughest thing to get right?

Danny: There were many problematic moments - mostly involving the main artists, for obvious reasons. When we blew up Martha’s flat, for instance, you have David, Freema, and John running out of the building, just before the blast. That kind of stuff’s very taxing: it’s not like we just turn up and rig the explosion! It takes weeks of preparation, evaluation, and conversation with production. We did several tests the day before and used a gas explosion, which makes it much more controllable than a pyro blast. The scene in which Jack fires at the TARDIS’ central column was also difficult, seeing as the TARDIS is quite a flammable set!

Danny: No, that was probably the scene in which police fire though the back window of a car with Martha driving, the Doctor in the passenger seat and Captain Jack in the back! summary:
VIDEO: Watch David Tennant's FanX Q&A Panel

  

David Tennant has spent the last couple of days in Salt Lake City, Utah...
caption:
VIDEO: Watch David Tennant’s FanX Q&A Panel

David Tennant has spent the last couple of days in Salt Lake City, Utah attending the FanX Salt Lake Comic Convention. As well as taking part in multiple photoshoots and signing sessions, he also answered questions for fans during a Q&A panel yesterday afternoon.

The packed out event was hosted by actor and stand-up comedian Jay Whittaker and sw David tackling questions on all aspects of his life and career. Among the topics discussed were:

- David’s introduction to the local delicacy ‘fry sauce’.
- David’s dancing abilities
- His upcoming projects: Camping for HBO, the new BBC series There She Goes (which David does not think will be shown in the US), the much anticipated Amazon prime adaptation of Good Omens and a DuckTales Christmas special.
- His work in Marvel’s Jessica Jones: David says that there are no immediate plans for a return for Kilgrave but added “…if there were immediate plans I’d be denying them”.
- Jodie Whittaker taking over as the Doctor in Doctor Who: “The Doctor can be anything and anyone. Any sense that Jodie is an unusual piece of casting will be banished by the time it takes to the screen…I can’t wait to see it.”
- His memories of filming Doctor Who: “…A different life, such an intense time”
- The Doctor Who theme tune: “I will never do show that has a theme tune that good again and then I ended up in DuckTales.”
- Broadchurch’s backstage shenanigans: “We laughed a lot - often inappropriately.”

tags: the woman who fell to earth
summary: Cinematic parallels ... (I mean if you really want to dig into symbolism - which is kinda absurd ‘cause I doubt that was on the...
caption:
Cinematic parallels …

(I mean if you really want to dig into symbolism - which is kinda absurd ‘cause I doubt that was on the mind of people that made the Jodie trailer, but hey, y’know, it’s fun -, there’s quite a lot of stuff here. Jodie makes everything blow while standing quietly on the floor: contrasting with a dying, desperate Doctor; you got one who’s just in control, happy and at the peak of her powers. Plus she was last seen, in the show, falling - except that trailer gives you the impression she managed to control the fall and escape the rather inelegant fate Ten encountered)

(throw on top the ‘breaking the glass ceiling’ metaphor and also a little bit of that Moffat era trend of the Doctor/religious edifices mix giving way to … interesting results [like, I dunno, the roof of Saint-Paul opening in “Death in Heaven”], and you’ve got yourself a really visually neat and interesting trailer, I’d say)

Cinematic parallels …

(I mean if you really want to dig into symbolism - which is kinda absurd ‘cause I doubt that was on the mind of people that made the Jodie trailer, but hey, y’know, it’s fun -, there’s quite a lot of stuff here. Jodie makes everything blow while standing quietly on the floor: contrasting with a dying, desperate Doctor; you got one who’s just in control, happy and at the peak of her powers. Plus she was last seen, in the show, falling - except that trailer gives you the impression she managed to control the fall and escape the rather inelegant fate Ten encountered)

(throw on top the ‘breaking the glass ceiling’ metaphor and also a little bit of that Moffat era trend of the Doctor/religious edifices mix giving way to … interesting results [like, I dunno, the roof of Saint-Paul opening in “Death in Heaven”], and you’ve got yourself a really visually neat and interesting trailer, I’d say)
